sn1.1:1.1.comm: Bhikkhu Bodhi’s Connected Discourses of the Buddha includes extensive discussions of variant readings, as well as summaries of the commentary. I don’t replicate these here, but usually I follow Bodhi’s readings and note where I differ.

sn1.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn1.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

sn1.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn1.1:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
sn1.1:1.3.comm: “Deity” is devatā, which in Pali as in English is an abstract noun. Though feminine in grammatical gender, it does not imply that the deity is female. Here, for example, the deity is addressed with the masculine form āvuso.

sn1.1:1.4.eng: “Good fellow, how did you cross the flood?”
sn1.1:1.4.comm: “Good fellow” (mārisa; Sanskrit mārṣa, māriṣa) is a special term of address used by deities and sometimes by kings. The term harks back to Sanskrit mādṛśa, “one like me”, in the sense of having a comparable status, i.e. “fellow”. | The Buddha lived and taught in the Gangetic plain, a region characterized by deadly and unpredictable flooding.

sn1.1:1.5.eng: “Neither standing nor swimming, good sir, I crossed the flood.”
sn1.1:1.5.comm: That āyūhati means “swim” is clear from SN 2.5:3.5.

sn1.1:1.6.pli: “Yathākathaṃ pana tvaṃ, mārisa, appatiṭṭhaṃ anāyūhaṃ oghamatarī”ti?
sn1.1:1.6.eng: “But in what way did you cross the flood neither standing nor swimming?”
sn1.1:1.6.comm: The deity’s counter-question shows that the Buddha’s answer was deliberately obscure.

sn1.1:1.8.eng: When I swam, I was swept away.

sn1.1:1.9.pli: Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, appatiṭṭhaṃ anāyūhaṃ oghamatarin”ti.
sn1.1:1.9.eng: That’s how I crossed the flood neither standing nor swimming.”
sn1.1:1.9.comm: The teaching suggests a state of poised flow, where one is neither stuck in attachments, nor restlessly straining to get somewhere else.

sn1.1:2.4.eng: he’s crossed over clinging to the world.”

sn1.1:3.1.eng: This is what that deity said,

sn1.1:3.4.pli: “samanuñño me satthā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn1.1:3.4.eng: Then that deity, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

sn1.10:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn1.10:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, that deity addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn1.10:2.3.eng: eat just one meal a day:

sn1.10:2.4.eng: so why is their complexion so clear?”

sn1.10:3.2.eng: nor do they pray for the future;
sn1.10:3.2.comm: Pajappanti , from jappa, means both to “incant” and to “long for”, and the English “pray’ has exactly the same connotations—for exactly the same reasons. They originated in begging favors of a god.

sn1.10:3.3.eng: they feed on whatever comes that day,

sn1.10:3.4.eng: that’s why their complexion’s so clear.

sn1.10:4.1.eng: Because they long for the future,

sn1.10:4.4.eng: like a green reed mowed down.”

sn1.11:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn1.11:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn1.11:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn1.11:2.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, aññatarā tāvatiṃsakāyikā devatā nandane vane accharāsaṅghaparivutā dibbehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārayamānā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.11:2.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a certain deity of the company of the thirty-three was amusing themselves in the Garden of Delight, escorted by a band of nymphs, and supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation. On that occasion she spoke this verse:

sn1.11:3.2.eng: who don’t see the Garden of Delight!

sn1.11:3.3.eng: It’s the abode of lordly gods,
sn1.11:3.3.comm: Naradeva is a term for a king. Here and at SN 9.6:4.3 it refers to the gods of the Thirty-Three, and at Thag 20.1:41.1 to Brahmā. At Cp 5:1.3 it apparently refers to the aristocrats who are “gods among men” (see Manu 11.82).

sn1.11:3.4.comm: Tidasa (“thirty”) is a poetic abbreviation for the “thirty-three” gods. Noted as such in Kṣīrasvāmin’s Amarakośodghāṭana 1.1.7.

sn1.11:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, aññatarā devatā taṃ devataṃ gāthāya paccabhāsi:
sn1.11:4.1.eng: When they had spoken, another deity replied with this verse:

sn1.11:5.1.comm: The vocative form bāle suggests that a female deity is being addressed, which is certainly the case in the parallel passage at SN 9.6:5.1. The commentary says that the speaker here is also a female deity.

sn1.11:5.2.eng: the saying of the perfected ones:

sn1.11:5.3.comm: This famous verse, which occurs many times in the Suttas, was spoken by the Buddha at SN 15.20:8.2 and by Sakka, the lord of the thirty-three, at the Buddha’s passing (SN 6.15:6.2, DN 16:6.10.11. | In this context, saṅkhārā means “conditions” or “conditioned phenomena” rather than “volitional actions”, “choices”. | The unusual reading sabbasaṅkhārā (rather than vata saṅkhārā) recurs in the parallel passage at SN 9.6:5.3.

sn1.11:5.4.eng: their nature is to rise and fall;

sn1.12:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.12:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, that deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.12:2.3.eng: For attachments are a man’s delight;

sn1.12:2.4.pli: Na hi so nandati yo nirūpadhī”ti.

sn1.12:3.3.eng: For attachments are a man’s sorrow;
sn1.12:3.3.comm: “Attachment” here is upadhi, which is both the things of the world to which we cling, and the inner clinging (see Snp 1.2, SN 12.66). The Jains defined upadhi similarly (Tattvārthasūtra 9.26). The dominant meaning in Sanskrit is “fraud”, which perhaps informs the Buddhist sense: the things we attach to give a false sense of security.

sn1.12:3.4.pli: Na hi so socati yo nirūpadhī”ti.
sn1.12:3.4.eng: without attachments there are no sorrows.”

sn1.13:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.13:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, that deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.13:2.1.eng: “There’s no fondness like that for a child,

sn1.13:2.2.comm: Vājasaneyi Saṁhitā 23.48b says cattle have no measure.

sn1.13:2.3.eng: no light like that of the sun,
sn1.13:2.3.comm: These lines closely mirror the question at Vājasaneyi Saṁhitā 23.47a (quoted at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.5.2.13), “What light equals the sun? What lake equals the ocean?” The answers given in the next verse are “Brahmā” and “heaven”.

sn1.13:2.4.eng: and of lakes the ocean is paramount.”

sn1.13:3.1.eng: “There’s no fondness like that for oneself,
sn1.13:3.1.comm: The Theravada tradition, starting from the Vimuttimagga, begins the meditation on love (mettā) by focusing on oneself, a practice that draws on passages such as this. See also SN 3.8, Ud 5.1. Here the Pali uses pema (“fondness”) rather than mettā (“love”).

sn1.13:3.3.eng: no light like that of wisdom,

sn1.13:3.4.eng: and of waters the rain is paramount.”

sn1.14:1.1.eng: “An aristocrat is the best of bipeds,
sn1.14:1.1.comm: Where the setting is omitted, it is assumed that a deity speaks and the Buddha answers.

sn1.14:1.2.eng: an ox is the best of quadrupeds,

sn1.14:1.3.eng: a maiden is the best of wives,

sn1.14:1.4.eng: and a first-born the best of sons.”

sn1.14:2.1.eng: “A Buddha is the best of bipeds,

sn1.14:2.2.eng: a thoroughbred, the best of quadrupeds,

sn1.14:2.3.eng: a good listener is the best of wives,
sn1.14:2.3.comm: Sussusati, literally “wanting to listen” is a precursor for wisdom (Snp 1.10:11.3), and is normally used of mendicants who want to learn the Dhamma (MN 122:26.4).

sn1.14:2.4.eng: and the best of sons is loyal.”

sn1.15:1.1.comm: These verses are also in SN 9.12.

sn1.15:1.2.eng: when the birds have settled down,

sn1.15:1.4.eng: that strikes me as so scary!”

sn1.15:2.2.eng: when the birds have settled down,

sn1.15:2.4.eng: that strikes me as so delightful!”

sn1.16:1.3.eng: because of this the noble path

sn1.16:2.3.eng: when this is energetically fended off,

sn1.17:1.2.eng: is the ascetic life for the inept,

sn1.17:1.3.eng: for it has many narrow passes

sn1.17:2.1.eng: “How many days could an ascetic live

sn1.17:2.4.comm: “Thought” here is saṅkappa, while below it is (mano)-vitakka.

sn1.17:3.1.eng: A mendicant should collect their thoughts

sn1.17:3.2.eng: as a tortoise draws its limbs into its shell.
sn1.17:3.2.comm: The simile is drawn out into a parable at SN 35.240, while the same simile is found in the Jain Isibhāsiyāiṁ chapter 16.

sn1.18:1.3.comm: The reading apabodhati is uncertain. It seems to be from the root bodh, which suggests the sense “be aware (of), be cognizant (of)”. This matches the answering verse, which speaks of mindfulness. The point is that by being aware of what is blameworthy they restrain themselves from it.

sn1.18:1.4.eng: like a fine horse of the whip?”

sn1.18:2.3.eng: Having reached the end of suffering,

sn1.18:2.4.eng: smoothly they walk in the rough.”

sn1.19:1.2.eng: Don’t you have a little nest?

sn1.19:1.3.comm: At SN 22.102:2.1 and AN 6.54:9.2, santānakā means “network of roots”, while at Kd 1:25.15.7 it means “cobwebs”.

sn1.19:2.2.eng: Indeed I have no little nest.

sn1.19:3.1.eng: “What do you think I call your little hut?

sn1.19:3.2.eng: What do I call your little nest?

sn1.19:3.3.eng: What do I call your network?

sn1.19:3.4.eng: And what do I call your shackle?”

sn1.19:4.4.eng: and you call my craving a shackle.”

sn1.19:5.1.eng: “It’s good you have no little hut!

sn1.19:5.2.eng: It’s good you have no little nest!

sn1.19:5.3.eng: It’s good you have no networks!

sn1.19:5.4.eng: And good that you’re free from shackles.”

sn1.2:1.1.comm: From here, the Pali gives only the abbreviated setting or none at all. In such cases, we are meant to read the full introduction per SN 1.1.

sn1.2:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn1.2:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

sn1.2:2.1.pli: “Jānāsi no tvaṃ, mārisa, sattānaṃ nimokkhaṃ pamokkhaṃ vivekan”ti?
sn1.2:2.1.eng: “Good fellow, do you know the liberation, emancipation, and seclusion of sentient beings?”

sn1.2:3.1.pli: “Jānāmi khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sattānaṃ nimokkhaṃ pamokkhaṃ vivekan”ti.

sn1.2:4.1.pli: “Yathākathaṃ pana tvaṃ, mārisa, jānāsi sattānaṃ nimokkhaṃ pamokkhaṃ vivekan”ti?
sn1.2:4.1.eng: “But how is it that you know the liberation, emancipation, and seclusion of sentient beings?”

sn1.2:5.1.eng: “Due to the ending of relish for rebirth;
sn1.2:5.1.comm: The Buddha’s answer seems to mix a few lines of verse with some prose. This line is verse, as it has an unusual structure, best understood as due to the exigencies of metre, and where it occurs elsewhere it is always as verse. Also, this line and the next are metrical (vatta). The Chinese parallels at SA 1268 and SA-2 179 format the whole of the Buddha’s answer as prose, the verse being spoken by the deity at the end. Perhaps the Buddha quoted a couple of lines of verse in a prose sentence.

sn1.2:5.2.eng: due to the finishing of perception and consciousness;
sn1.2:5.2.comm: With this the Buddha differentiates himself from Yājnavalkya, for whom perception (limited awareness) ends, but consciousness (infinite awareness) is eternal (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12).

sn1.2:5.3.eng: due to the cessation and stilling of feelings—
sn1.2:5.3.comm: The Chinese parallels here speak of the liberation of the mind rather than the cessation of feelings. The textual problems seem insoluble and it appears the text is corrupt.

sn1.2:5.4.eng: that, good sir, is how I know the liberation,

sn1.2:5.5.eng: emancipation, and seclusion of sentient beings.”
